Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery cup, possibly a Type A kantharos; white slip; interior: glazed (fired orange) with traces of rosette petals in added white; exterior: painted decoration consisting of female figure's himation and outstretched left hand; at right, part of glazed (fired brown) zone, possibly part of an architectural feature; painted inscription in field.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos identifies the same sherd as both a Grand Style chalice (1991, 281) and a Chalice Style kantharos (1991, 297). Although painted inscriptions are frequently found on kantharoi, they are not exclusive to those vessels. Very little remains of the figural representation, it could belong to either group. For parallels, see British Museum 1924,1201.390. If this sherd belongs to a kantharos, it belongs in Williams' Type A group (Williams, D. ‘Aigina, Aphaia-Tempel 5. The pottery from Chios’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 1983, 169). Kantharoi in this group are dated between 600BC-575BC and these predate the Chalice Style.
Bibliographic references: Cook & Woodhead 1952 / Painted Inscriptions on Chiot Pottery (p. 165, no. 25)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 34, no. 51, pl. XVII)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 281, no. 779, pl. 102, p. 297, no. 977)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1661) (phase 2)
